title: S the state of California tax board allowed to take money out of my bank account from an insurance claim?
question: The government has been taking money out of my bank account for a few years because of fines on parking tickets and criminal fines. I recently received a check from my insurance company to pay my hospital bill and am worried that if I put the money in my bank account the government will take the money I am supposed to be using to pay my hospital bill. benefits from a workplace accident. Is there a way to prevent the money from being taken or for me to get it back in the case I have to deposit the money?
answers:
You should try to resolve the issue with the taxing authority, either by entering into a payment plan or possibly obtaining a settlement. With respect to your insurance check, why don't you just cash it?

As you have learned, the Franchise Tax Board is very aggressive in collecting past due taxes and other debts owed to the state. Their position--supported by state law--is that payment of obligations to the state take priority over other debts or obligations you may have. Therefore, if you deposit an insurance check into your bank account, the funds are considered your property and are "fair game". I would not recommend trying to "hide" the funds in another account, since that could constitute a "fraudulent conveyance", which is both a civil and criminal offense. If an FTB levy or seizure of the funds would constitute an economic hardship for you, it would be best to contact the FTB-Advocate's office (listed on FTB website). Even though it's not a tax obligation, they may be able to assist with your hardship circumstances.

Can you open a new bank account in another bank and disburse the funds, then close that account? In theory, you could try to file with the levying officer a claim of exemption, but it takes weeks to have the court decide if the state objects. Also, perhaps you can find out if the state's claims and other fines have been paid in full and get a written document from the state that the bills have been satisfied in full, thus the bank levy should be removed, and your funds no longer at risk.
